message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus and deep vein thrombosis, and the positive VDRL test result and failure to correct aPTT suggest the most likely cause is antiphospholipid syndrome. Protein S deficiency, mutation of Leiden V factor, and antithrombin deficiency can also lead to thrombosis but do not have the same clinical context as this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of systemic lupus erythematosus, stroke, deep vein thrombosis, and positive VDRL test suggest the most likely cause is antiphospholipid syndrome. The mixing studies not correcting aPTT also support this diagnosis. Protein S deficiency, mutation of Leiden V factor, and antithrombin deficiency are all causes of thrombophilia but are less likely given the patient’s history and laboratory results.

The patient has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, stroke, deep vein thrombosis, and multiple spontaneous abortions which are all risk factors for antiphospholipid syndrome. The positive VDRL test and the failure to correct aPTT in mixing studies are also indicative of antiphospholipid syndrome. Protein S deficiency, mutation of Leiden V factor, and antithrombin deficiency may cause hypercoagulable states, but they are not likely to be the cause in this patient given her clinical presentation and test results.
